text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
DAWN
- Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda said he was ready for holding foreign minister-level talks with Pakistan, the Press Trust of India said.
- The European Union election observers' group monitored serious deficiencies in the electoral process and advised Pakistan to hold an early census to avoid distortions in the system.
- Afghanistan's Taleban militia said the election of Nawaz Sharif as Pakistan's new prime minister would make no difference to Kabul's ties with Islamabad.
- The Central Executive Committee of the Pakistan People's Party said the February 3 elections were massively rigged and refused to accept its results.

- The U.S. State Department congratulated Nawaz Sharif on his party's big win in Pakistan as a spokesman rejected allegations of electoral irregularities and promised to work cooperatively with the new government.
- China congratulated Nawaz Sharif and his Pakistan Muslim League for their landslide victory in the general elections.
BUSINESS RECORDER

- The Federation of Pakistan Chambers of Commerce and Industry suggested immediate confidence-building steps to restore the bruised hopes of the nation which suffered because of the lopsided, anti-people policies of the PPP government.
- Pakistan Muslim League will form a government in Sindh with the cooperation of its allies, a PML spokesman said.

- Pakistan's ousted prime minister Benazir Bhutto, trying to come to terms with a crushing election defeat, deferred a decision on whether to boycott the national and provincial assemblies after huddling with party colleagues.
- The caretakers will transfer power to the elected government when the new national and provincial assemblies hold their inaugural sessions between February 15 and 20.
JANG
- The International Monetary Fund asked the government to retire government employees who have completed 30 years in service or have reached the age of 55.
- The Pakistan People's Party led by Benazir Bhutto will not cooperate with Jamaat-i-Islami in its anti-government movement.
THE NEWS
- Caretaker Law Minister Shahid Hamid said the new government would be in office on February 16 and the prime minister would take oath of his office the same day.
- The incumbent prime minister Nawaz Sharif has asked overseas Pakistanis to invest $1,000 each through official channels to increase the foreign exchange reserves.
- The United States intelligence officials said on Wednesday that India and Pakistan could stumble into an unwanted war that could escalate into a nuclear exchange.
-- Islamabad newsroom 9251-274757
